abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Mine Township Services
            Project for Zambia were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: Clear and predictable tariff
            setting mechanisms and regulatory approvals are a key
            support element for the implementation of a utility
            commercialization strategy. Time requirements for
            reconnaissance of a deteriorated network need to be
            realistically assessed to ensure suitable project design.
            For a project that is set up as a transitional solution, the
            process/roadmap for determining the exit strategy should be
            clearly defined, key stakeholders should be involved
            throughout that process, the implementing agency should be
            given an appropriately strong mandate, and the Bank should
            ensure that it is closely associated with it. Communication
            should include decision makers and political leaders, be
            continuous and should if required be supported under the
            project. It is unrealistic to anticipate large labor/staff
            cost savings in a situation where a utility is changing from
            an inefficient non-commercial public sector setting to a
            commercial focus.

5084848.trustfund:
TF039651-ZAMBIA - MINING TOWNSHIP
            SERVICES PROJECT,TF039345-ZAMBIA - MINING TOWNSHIP
            SERVICES - WATER AND SANITATION EXPERT,TF025657-PHRD-URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF038650-ZAMBIA:  MINE TOWNSHIP SERVICES PROJECT,TF038089-ZAMBIA - MINING TOWNSHIP SERVICES,TF037932-ZAMBIA - MINING MUNICIPAL
5084848.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Human development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Mine Township Services Project is
            intended to facilitate the completion of the privatization
            of ZCCM (Zambia Consolidate Copper Mines) by supporting the
            provision of efficient and reliable water supply services,
            wastewater services and solid waste management in five mine
            townships during a transitional period following the
            privatization. There are three project components. The first
            and second components will be implemented through the AHC
            Mining Municipal Services (AHC-MMS) and the third component
            through the Ministry of Local Government and Housing. The
            first component consists of a) Performance Based Management
            Contract, which will be managed between the AHC-MMS and the
            private operator; b) Production Costs Support and Start-up
            Costs, the monies to finance the AHC-MMS's operation
            and maintenance support which include computer equipment for
            finance and engineering activities; and c) Rehabilitation
            Works, which include rehabilitation of water mains and water
            and wastewater treatment plants. The second component will
            provide support to employees of AHC-MMS and their families,
            and increase the awareness of HIV/AIDS throughout the
            community. The third component will support the preparation
            of a permanent system for the delivery of urban development
            in the selected Copperbelt towns and cities by acting as
            demonstration project for the use of private sector
            contracting to achieve sustainable results.

repnme.cdata!:
Zambia - Mine Township Services Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The area related to the Mine Township
            Services Project is located in the Copperbelt Province,
            influenced by the flow regime of the upper Kafue River
            basin, where human interventions, in addition to geophysical
            characteristics, and a number of water usage and management
            activities, have had an adverse environmental impact on the
            area, particularly as it regards water and air pollution,
            solid waste generation, and, deforestation. Since the
            construction of the project poses further environmental
            risks on the area, the Environmental Assessment (EA)
            presents mitigating measures, addressing in particular
            sewage effluent issues, which have permanently changed the
            ecological system of streams flowing into the Kafue River.
            Measures re-enforce the need to assure that the management
            contract include raw water quantity, and quality monitoring,
            which includes waste water management, i.e., quality of
            treated effluents, and equipment investments. Furthermore,
            the need for a training component for water supply, and
            sanitation systems' operators is addressed, as well as
            the risk of cross contamination of water supply,
            recommending separation of workers dealing with clean water,
            from those with residual waters, and, a solid waste
            management component is recommended, outlining a number of
            sub-component activities. Involuntary resettlement has been
            identified as a direct consequence of the project.

display_title.display_title:
Zambia - Mine Township Services
            Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 2) : Photographs
